title: How to Keep Rose Petals Fresh

methods.name: Using Harvesting Techniques to Keep Petals Fresh

steps.headline: Pick petals from fresh roses.
steps.description: It's important to use very fresh roses if you are harvesting petals. If you are harvesting your own roses, make sure the bush is hydrated before you cut the flowers. To do this, water the plant the night before you cut the flowers.

steps.headline: Make sure you cut young flowers in the early morning before the day heats up.
steps.description: Use a sharp knife to cut the stem. A clean cut means the stem will absorb water better than if you inflict a crushing cut from a blunt tool. Try to make a diagonal (slanting) cut rather than a straight, square one. Doing this increases the area of cell tissue exposed to water so that the stem can drink more.

steps.headline: Avoid harvesting roses just after it has rained as the petals will be moist.
steps.description: It's important the rose petals are dry when you store them. If this is unavoidable, lay the petals out on a clean dry towel after harvesting and gently pat them dry.

steps.headline: Keep your cut flowers cool until you are ready to pluck the petals.
steps.description: Place your cut flowers in cool water in a clean container such as a vase until you are ready to use them. It's a good idea to keep the vase in as cool a position as possible. A cool cellar or garage works well; at the very least store the vase away from direct sunlight and drafts. You should avoid placing the vase near electrical appliances such as TVs as these emit heat. Try to change the water every other day.

steps.headline: Pluck petals from closed blooms.
steps.description: Try to use a young, slightly closed rose bloom for taking petals rather than a fully open one or any bloom that is starting to drop petals voluntarily. However, don't use buds that are too young and tightly closed. The bloom should be just about to open.

methods.name: Using the Fridge to Keep Petals Fresh

steps.headline: Remove the petals from the flower.
steps.description:
Gently shake off any insects and discard any damaged blooms or petals. To remove the petals from the rose:
Grip the closed bud very lightly just below the petals. Squeeze around the base just below the petals and gently twist the stem to loosen the petals. Grip very carefully to avoid bruising your petals.

steps.headline: Wet a paper towel.
steps.description: Take a paper towel or paper napkin, fold it a few times, and wet it slightly. It should be able to hold the water like a sponge without dripping. Place the wet paper towel into a clear plastic bag or plastic freezer bag (ideally one with a zip closure or press seal). Alternately you can use a tupperware container or some kind of plastic box such as an old margarine or ice cream container. Just make sure it's clean and dry.

steps.headline: Put the wet paper towel at the bottom of your bag or container.
steps.description: Place the rose petals on top of the paper towel. Don't cram them into the bag or box as they are likely to bruise and break. Use several bags or boxes if required. Air should be able to circulate around the rose petals; this will help prevent them from rotting.

steps.headline: Close the bag using the zip lock or put the lid on the box.
steps.description: Put the bag carefully into the fridge. Place your contained rose petals on their own shelf so that nothing can fall on them. You can stack the bags on top of each other but make sure nothing heavy rests on them. Make sure that they don't touch any part of the fridge that may cause them to freeze. For example, don't let them touch the back wall of the fridge as this is sometimes icy and will freeze them. Freezing will cause your petals to become mushy.

steps.headline: Take the bags out every other day until you use them.
steps.description: It's important to take the bags out every other day. Give the bag a gentle shake and turn it over. This stops the petals from sticking together and helps air circulate in the bags.

steps.headline: Store your petals for three to seven days.
steps.description: It's sometimes possible to keep rose petals fresh for up to a week in a fridge but try to take them out before the seven days are up. Ideally you should use the rose petals as quickly as possible after harvesting them. Try to use the petals within three days of plucking them from the flower.

steps.headline: Consider drying your rose petals after you have used them.
steps.description: After using your petals for your event, you can try drying them for use in potpourri. Lay them out in a single layer in a dark dry place for about two weeks. Once dry, put the petals in a clean, dry jar. Add some drops of rose essential oil. Give the jar a shake every few days for about a month before adding it to potpourri.
